newsitem.title: ROMANIA: Romania hails oil block tender as success.
newsitem.headline: Romania hails oil block tender as success.

text.p: Romania's National Agency for Mineral Resources (ANRM) said on Wednesday it had received eight "block-offers" from companies bidding in a tender for 15 onshore and offshore oil blocks.
"We can say the tender was a success. We received eight block-offers for areas which are geologically interesting," Doru Badulescu, head of ANRM, told a news conference.

In April, ANRM put up for tender nine prospective oil blocks chain-linked along the eastern rim of the Carpathians, two near the northern border with Hungary and Ukraine, two in southern Romania and two on the Black Sea continental shelf.
ANMR sources said 47 companies had bought packages of data on the 15 blocks on offer.
Badulescu declined to identify the company or companies which submitted offers, or elaborate on "block-offers".

"At this stage everything is confidential," Badulescu said, adding that the ANRM had set a January 31 deadline to evaluate the offers. Winning bidders would be able to start work on the blocks by next June.
Badulescu said the blocks chosen by the bidding companies covered "interesting and complex geological areas".
Romania needs capital and modern technology to discover oil deposits in deep or difficult structures. Local oil companies can drill only to depths of 4,000 metres.

Agency sources said potential winners in the tender would invest a minimum $30 million and be able to drill at depths exceeding 4,000 metres. Technology transfer and training programmes were additional assets.
A Western oil expert was reluctant to describe the tender as a success but told Reuters it was a positive step to attract major investors to Romania's oil sector.

"It's very unclear what those eight block-offers mean but its better than no offers at all," the expert said. "The fact that they got offers at all is positive and could send encouraging signs to strategic investors."
Seeking an increase in oil output in 1991, Romania offered concessions to firms including Royal/Dutch Shell Group, Enterprise Oil Plc and Amoco Corp.
Romania is a mature oil and gas producing region. But frenzied exploitation of reserves by the former communists and poor equipment depressed crude output over the past 20 years.
Crude production was around 6.7 million tonnes (equivalent to about 134,000 barrels per day) last year, compared to a peak of 14.7 million tonnes (294,000 bpd) in 1986.

Under a new petroleum law, Romania puts local and foreign investors on an equal footing. The law covers concessions, taxes and royalties and includes a one-year profit tax exemption following the start-up of production. --Adrian Dascalu, Bucharest newsroom +401 312-0264
